In early 1962, in the wake of the disastrous Great Leap Forward, Mao resigned from the first line of responsibilities in the PRC affairs, leaving day-to-day operation to his senior associates Liu Shaoqi, Zhou Enlai, and Deng Xiaoping. Mao retired to a second line role, focusing on policymaking and theoretical research. Thus, Mingjiang Li’s assertion that “Wang did not submit the report to Mao, the actual decision-maker on China’s international strategies, indicates the subtle different strategic considerations between other leaders and Mao” is untenable. Yafeng Xia is professor of history at Long Island University in New York and Senior Research Fellow, Institute for Studies of China’s Neighboring Countries and Regions at East China Normal University in Shanghai. A former Wilson Center fellow and public policy scholar, he is the author of Negotiating with the Enemy: U.S.-China Talks during the Cold War

note: He has coauthored a new book, entitled A Misunderstood Friendship: Mao Zedong, Kim Il-sung, and Sino-North Korean Relations, 1949–1976 (September 2018).
title: A New History, with Zhihua Shen
He has also published many articles on Cold War history
